title: Forest in advanced talks to appoint manager Dyche
summary: Nottingham Forest are in advanced talks to appoint former Burnley and Everton boss Sean Dyche as their manager.

title: 'A little Magpie' - why Mourinho 'loves' Newcastle
summary: Jose Mourinho's Benfica face Newcastle in the Champions League on Tuesday - but why does the Portuguese boss consider himself "a little Magpie"?

title: Apple TV, Apple Music and App Store are down as Apple services suffer major outage
summary: Update: The Apple system status now says Apple TV, Apple Music and App Store issues are now resolved. Apple online services are currently experience a big outage that has lasted a couple hours already. Some customers are noticing they are unable to stream on Apple TV, listen to their library on Appâ€¦

title: DeepSeek OCR
summary: Comments

title: Boulter's poor run continues with first-round loss
summary: British number three Katie Boulter continues her poor run of form with defeat by German Eva Lys in the second round of the Pan Pacific Open.

title: Why Colts are real contenders as Denver defy odds
summary: The Indianapolis Colts cement their place as genuine contenders while Bo Nix leads an incredible comeback for the Denver Broncos.

title: Consign my Ashes try to history - Davies' England challenge
summary: Thirty-one years ago this week, Jonathan Davies scored arguably Wembley's greatest-ever try. This Saturday, he wants to see England produce a memorable moment to match it.

title: Goal of the season contender? MOTD pundits on 'world-class' Buendia
summary: Match of the Day pundit and ex-Aston Villa goalkeeper Shay Given describes Emiliano Buendia's winning goal in Villa's 2-1 win over Tottenham in the Premier League as "world class".

title: The ultimate Ashes competitor - Broad on walking, Warner and that final wicket
summary: In the first of a new series of From the Ashes, Stuart Broad reflects on his legendary career, including battles with David Warner, his 8-15 and fairytale farewell.

title: Isak doesn't deserve start over Ekitike - Rooney
summary: British-record signing Alexander Isak is doing enough to justify starting ahead of Hugo Ekitike for Liverpool, says former England striker Wayne Rooney.

title: Something from â€œspaceâ€ may have just struck a United Airlines flight over Utah
summary: "NTSB gathering radar, weather, flight recorder data."
body: The National Transportation Safety Board confirmed Sunday that it is investigating an airliner that was struck by an object in its windscreen, mid-flight, over Utah. â€œNTSB gathering radar, weather, flight recorder data,â€ the federal agency said on the social media site X . â€œWindscreen being sent to NTSB laboratories for examination.â€ The strike occurred Thursday, during a United Airlines flight from Denver to Los Angeles. Images shared on social media showed that one of the two large windows at the front of a 737 MAX aircraft was significantly cracked. Related images also reveal a pilotâ€™s arm that has been cut multiple times by what appear to be small shards of glass. Read full article Comments

title: Roberta Williamsâ€™ The Colonelâ€™s Bequest was a different type of adventure game
summary: What if point-and-click games weren't about the puzzles?
body: Even in my youth, I always loved the idea of point-and-click adventure games more than I did the reality. I appreciated how they transported me to other worlds, each with its own rules, histories, and interesting characters. However, like many people, I often ran up against the harsh reality of solving bizarre and obtuse puzzles in a time before Internet walkthroughs. I almost never actually finished point-and-click adventure games for that reasonâ€”but there is one major exception: I completed Roberta Williamsâ€™ The Colonelâ€™s Bequest several times. One of the last Sierra adventure games to still use a text parser, The Colonelâ€™s Bequest follows a young woman named Laura Bow as she visits a mansion in the Southern US belonging to her college friendâ€™s grandfather, Colonel Henri Dijon. While sheâ€™s there, a dispute breaks out over the colonelâ€™s will, and it becomes clear a murderer is on the loose. Read full article Comments

title: Vaginal condition treatment update: Men should get treated, too
summary: For bacterial vaginosis, partners are part of the problemâ€”and the solution.
body: For some cases of bacterial vaginosis, treatment should include a package deal, doctors now say. The American College of Obstetricians & Gynecologists (ACOG) updated its clinical guidance Friday to fit with recent data indicating that treatment for recurring bacterial vaginosis (BV) in women is significantly more effective if their male partners are also treated at the same timeâ€”with both an oral antibiotic and an antibiotic cream directly onto the potentially offending member. â€œPartner therapy offers us another avenue for hopefully preventing recurrence and helping people feel better faster,â€ Christopher Zahn, chief of clinical practice and health equity and quality at ACOG, said in a statement. title: Ring cameras are about to get increasingly chummy with law enforcement
summary: Amazon's Ring partners with company whose tech has reportedly been used by ICE.
body: Law enforcement agencies will soon have easier access to footage captured by Amazonâ€™s Ring smart cameras. In a partnership announced this week, Amazon will allow approximately 5,000 local law enforcement agencies to request access to Ring camera footage via surveillance platforms from Flock Safety . Ring cooperating with law enforcement and the reported use of Flock technologies by federal agencies, including US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), has resurfaced privacy concerns that have followed the devices for years. According to Flockâ€™s announcement, its Ring partnership allows local law enforcement members to use Flock software â€œto send a direct post in the Ring Neighbors app with details about the investigation and request voluntary assistance.â€ Requests must include â€œspecific location and timeframe of the incident, a unique investigation code, and details about what is being investigated,â€ and users can look at the requests anonymously, Flock said. â€œAny footage a Ring customer chooses to submit will be securely packaged by Flock and shared directly with the requesting local public safety agency through the FlockOS or Flock Nova platform,â€ the announcement reads. Readâ€¦

title: Big Tech sues Texas, says age-verification law is â€œbroad censorship regimeâ€
summary: Texas app law compared to checking IDs at bookstores and shopping malls.
body: Texas is being sued by a Big Tech lobby group over the stateâ€™s new law that will require app stores to verify usersâ€™ ages and impose restrictions on users under 18. â€œThe Texas App Store Accountability Act imposes a broad censorship regime on the entire universe of mobile apps,â€ the Computer & Communications Industry Association (CCIA) said yesterday in a lawsuit . â€œIn a misguided attempt to protect minors, Texas has decided to require proof of age before anyone with a smartphone or tablet can download an app. Anyone under 18 must obtain parental consent for every app and in-app purchase they try to downloadâ€”from ebooks to email to entertainment.â€ The CCIA said in a press release that the law violates the First Amendment by imposing â€œa sweeping age-verification, parental consent, and compelled speech regime on both app stores and app developers.â€ When app stores determine that a user is under 18, â€œthe law prohibits them from downloading virtually all apps and software programs and from making any in-app purchases unless their parent consents and is given control over the minorâ€™s account,â€ the CCIA said. â€œMinors who are unable to link their accounts with a parentâ€™s or guardianâ€™sâ€¦

title: 12 years of HDD analysis brings insight to the bathtub curveâ€™s reliability
summary: Backup firm brings a unique, informed perspective to HDD failure rates.
body: Backblaze is a backup and cloud storage company that has been tracking the annualized failure rates (AFRs) of the hard drives in its datacenter since 2013. As you can imagine, thatâ€™s netted the firm a lot of data. And that data has led the company to conclude that HDDs â€œare lasting longerâ€ and showing fewer errors. That conclusion came from a blog post this week by Stephanie Doyle, Backblazeâ€™s writer and blog operations specialist, and Pat Patterson, Backblazeâ€™s chief technical evangelist. The authors compared the AFRs for the approximately 317,230 drives in Backblazeâ€™s datacenter to the AFRs the company recorded when examining the 21,195 drives it had in 2013 and 206,928 drives in 2021 . Doyle and Patterson said they identified â€œa pretty solid deviation in both age of drive failure and the high point of AFR from the last two times weâ€™ve run the analyses.â€ Credit: Backblaze Read full article Comments

title: Lead poisoning has been a feature of our evolution
summary: A recent study found lead in teeth from 2 million-year-old hominin fossils.
body: Our hominid ancestors faced a Pleistocene world full of dangersâ€”and apparently one of those dangers was lead poisoning. Lead exposure sounds like a modern problem, at least if you define â€œmodernâ€ the way a paleoanthropologist might: a time that started a few thousand years ago with ancient Roman silver smelting and lead pipes. According to a recent study, however, lead is a much more ancient nemesis, one that predates not just the Romans but the existence of our genus Homo . Paleoanthropologist Renaud Joannes-Boyau of Australiaâ€™s Southern Cross University and his colleagues found evidence of exposure to dangerous amounts of lead in the teeth of fossil apes and hominins dating back almost 2 million years. And somewhat controversially, they suggest that the toxic elementâ€™s pervasiveness may have helped shape our evolutionary history. The skull of an early hominid. Credit: Einsamer SchÃ¼tze / Wikimedia The Romans didnâ€™t invent lead poisoning Joannes-Boyau and his colleagues took tiny samples of preserved enamel and dentin from the teeth of 51 fossils. In most of those teeth, the paleoanthropologists found evidence that these apes and hominins had been exposed to leadâ€”sometimes in dangâ€¦

title: 3 years, 4 championships, but 0 Le Mans wins: Assessing the Porsche 963
summary: Riding high in IMSA but pulling out of WEC paints a complicated picture for the factory team.
body: Porsche provided flights from Washington to Atlanta and accommodation so Ars could attend Petit Le Mans. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. The car world has long had a thing about numbers. Engine outputs. Top speeds. Zero-to-60 times. Displacement. But the numbers go beyond bench racing specs. Some cars have numbers for names, and few more memorably than Porsche. Its most famous model shares its appellation with the emergency services here in North America; although the car should accurately be â€œnine-11,â€ you call it â€œnine-one-one.â€ Some numbers are less well-known, but perhaps more special to Porscheâ€™s fans, especially those who like racing. 908. 917. 956. 962. 919. But how about 963? Thatâ€™s Porscheâ€™s current sports prototype, a 670-hp (500 kW) hybrid that for the last three years has battled against rivals in what is starting to look like, if not a golden era for endurance racing, then at least a very purple patch. And the 963 has done well, racing here in IMSAâ€™s WeatherTech Sportscar Championship and around the globe in the FIA World Endurance Championship. Read full article Comments

title: Teachers get an F on AI-generated lesson plans
summary: AI-generated lesson plans fall short on inspiring students and promoting critical thinking.
body: When teachers rely on commonly used artificial intelligence chatbots to devise lesson plans, it does not result in more engaging, immersive, or effective learning experiences compared with existing techniques, we found in our recent study . The AI-generated civics lesson plans we analyzed also left out opportunities for students to explore the stories and experiences of traditionally marginalized people. The allure of generative AI as a teaching aid has caught the attention of educators. A Gallup survey from September 2025 found that 60 percent of K-12 teachers are already using AI in their work , with the most common reported use being teaching preparation and lesson planning. Without the assistance of AI, teachers might spend hours every week crafting lessons for their students. With AI, time-stretched teachers can generate detailed lesson plans featuring learning objectives, materials, activities, assessments, extension activities, and homework tasks in a matter of seconds. Read full article Comments

title: Rocket Report: China launches with no advance warning; Europeâ€™s drone ship
summary: Starlink, Kuiper, and the US military all saw additions to their mega-constellations this week.
body: Welcome to Edition 8.15 of the Rocket Report! This year has been, at best, one of mixed results for SpaceXâ€™s Starship program. There have been important steps forward, including the successful reuse of the rocketâ€™s massive Super Heavy booster. Clearly, SpaceX is getting really good at launching and recovering the 33-engine booster stage. But Starship itself, part spacecraft and part upper stage, hasnâ€™t fared as well â€”at least it hadnâ€™t until the last couple of months. After four Starships were destroyed in flight and on the ground in the first half of 2025, the last two missions ended with pinpoint splashdowns in the Indian Ocean. The most recent mission this week was arguably the most successful yet for Starship, which returned to Earth with little damage, suggesting SpaceXâ€™s improvements to the heat shield are working. As always, we welcome reader submissions . If you donâ€™t want to miss an issue, please subscribe using the box below (the form will not appear on AMP-enabled versions of the site). Each report will include information on small-, medium-, and heavy-lift rockets, as well as a quick look ahead at the next three launches on the calendar. SpaceX vet will fly with Blue Oâ€¦

title: Yes, everything online sucks nowâ€”but it doesnâ€™t have to
summary: Ars chats with Cory Doctorow about his new book Enshittification.
body: We all feel it: Our once-happy digital spaces have become increasingly less user-friendly and more toxic, cluttered with extras nobody asked for and hardly anybody wants. Thereâ€™s even a word for it: â€œenshittification,â€ named 2023 Word of the Year by the American Dialect Society. The term was coined by tech journalist/science fiction author Cory Doctorow , a longtime advocate of digital rights. Doctorow has spun his analysis of whatâ€™s been ailing the tech industry into an eminently readable new book, Enshittification: Why Everything Suddenly Got Worse and What To Do About It . As Doctorow tells it, he was on vacation in Puerto Rico, staying in a remote cabin nestled in a cloud forest with microwave Internet serviceâ€”i.e., very bad Internet service, since microwave signals struggle to penetrate through clouds. It was a 90-minute drive to town, but when they tried to consult TripAdvisor for good local places to have dinner one night, they couldnâ€™t get the site to load. â€œAll you would get is the little TripAdvisor logo as an SVG filling your whole tab and nothing else,â€ Doctorow told Ars. â€œSo I tweeted, â€˜Has anyone at TripAdvisor ever been on a trip? This is the most enshittified websiâ€¦

title: RFK Jr.â€™s MAHA wants to make chemtrail conspiracy theories great again
summary: It's unclear if Kennedy will follow through, but he supports the conspiracy theory.
body: A prominent voice in the Make America Healthy Again movement is pushing for health secretary and anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to make the topic of chemtrail conspiracy theories a federal priority, according to a report by KFF News. KFF obtained a memo , written by MAHA influencer Gray Delany in July, presenting the topic to Calley Means, a White House health advisor. The memo lays out a series of unsubstantiated and far-fetched claims that academic researchers and federal agencies are secretively spreading toxic substances from airplanes, poisoning Americans, and spurring large-scale weather events, such as the devastating flooding in Texas last summer. â€œIt is unconscionable that anyone should be allowed to spray known neurotoxins and environmental toxins over our nationâ€™s citizens, their land, food and water supplies,â€ Delany writes in the memo. Read full article Comments

title: AI-powered features begin creeping deeper into the bedrock of Windows 11
summary: Copilot expands with an emphasis on creating and editing files, voice input.
body: Like virtually every major Windows announcement in the last three years, the spate of features that Microsoft announced for the operating system today all revolve around generative AI. In particular, theyâ€™re concerned with the companyâ€™s more recent preoccupation with â€œagenticâ€ AI, an industry buzzword for â€œtelling AI-powered software to perform a task, which it then does in the background while you move on to other things.â€ But the overarching impression I got, both from reading the announcement and sitting through a press briefing earlier this month, is that Microsoft is using language models and other generative AI technologies to try again with Cortana, Microsoftâ€™s failed and discontinued entry in the voice assistant wars of the 2010s. According to Microsoftâ€™s Consumer Chief Marketing Officer Yusuf Mehdi, â€œAI PCsâ€ should be able to recognize input â€œnaturally, in text or voice,â€ to be able to guide users based on whatâ€™s on their screens at any given moment, and that AI assistants â€œshould be able to take action on your behalf.â€ Read full article Comments

title: Nation-state hackers deliver malware from â€œbulletproofâ€ blockchains
summary: Malicious payloads stored on Ethereum and BNB blockchains are immune to takedowns.
body: Hacking groupsâ€”at least one of which works on behalf of the North Korean governmentâ€”have found a new and inexpensive way to distribute malware from â€œbulletproofâ€ hosts: stashing them on public cryptocurrency blockchains. In a Thursday post , members of the Google Threat Intelligence Group said the technique provides the hackers with their own â€œbulletproofâ€ host, a term that describes cloud platforms that are largely immune from takedowns by law enforcement and pressure from security researchers. More traditionally, these hosts are located in countries without treaties agreeing to enforce criminal laws from the US and other nations. These services often charge hefty sums and cater to criminals spreading malware or peddling child sexual abuse material and wares sold in crime-based flea markets. Next-gen, DIY hosting that canâ€™t be tampered with Since February, Google researchers have observed two groups turning to a newer technique to infect targets with credential stealers and other forms of malware. The method, known as EtherHiding, embeds the malware in smart contracts, which are essentially apps that reside on blockchains for Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies. Two or more partiâ€¦

title: Ars Live recap: Is the AI bubble about to pop? Ed Zitron weighs in.
summary: Despite connection hiccups, we covered OpenAI's finances, nuclear power, and Sam Altman.
body: On Tuesday of last week, Ars Technica hosted a live conversation with Ed Zitron, host of the Better Offline podcast and one of techâ€™s most vocal AI critics, to discuss whether the generative AI industry is experiencing a bubble and when it might burst. My Internet connection had other plans, though, dropping out multiple times and forcing Ars Technicaâ€™s Lee Hutchinson to jump in as an excellent emergency backup host. During the times my connection cooperated, Zitron and I covered OpenAIâ€™s financial issues, lofty infrastructure promises, and why the AI hype machine keeps rolling despite some arguably shaky economics underneath. Leeâ€™s probing questions about per-user costs revealed a potential flaw in AI subscription models: Companies canâ€™t predict whether a user will cost them $2 or $10,000 per month. You can watch a recording of the event on YouTube or in the window below. Read full article Comments
